skills.name: Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram
Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram

explanations.A: Not quite. The question says the ball is not replaced which means after the first pick you will not have 7 left in the bag. How many balls will you have left? How many of them will be red?
explanations.B: Not quite. We haven't picked a red ball yet, the first ball we picked was yellow.
explanations.C: Not quite. The question says the ball is not replaced which means after the first pick you will not have 7 left in the bag. How many balls will you have left?
explanations.D: If the first ball is yellow, there will be four red balls left out of a total of 6, so the probability is 4/6.

explanations.A: Not quite. The question says the ball is not replaced which means after the first pick you will not have 9 left in the bag. How many balls will you have left?
explanations.B: If the first ball is yellow, there will be five red balls left out of a total of 8, so the probability is 5/8.
explanations.C: Not quite. The question says the ball is not replaced which means after the first pick you will not have 9 left in the bag. How many balls will you have left? How many of them will be red?
explanations.D: Not quite. We haven't picked a red ball yet, the first ball we picked was yellow.

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you have tried to add rather than multiply.
explanations.B: Not quite. Have a look at your fractions. The denominators should be different as the balls are not replaced.
explanations.C: Not quite. Have a look at your fractions. The balls are not replaced, which means the number of red balls you have should go down.
explanations.D: We have 4/7 × 3/6 = 12/42. Even though the question states that both balls are picked out at the same time, one will be chosen before the other, making this a 'non-replace' type question.

explanations.A: Not quite. Have a look at your fractions. The denominators should be different as the balls are not replaced.
explanations.B: Not quite. Have a look at your fractions. The balls are not replaced, which means the number of red balls you have should go down.
explanations.C: We have 5/9 × 4/8 = 20/72. Even though the question states that both balls are picked out at the same time, one will be chosen before the other, making this a 'non-replace' type question.
explanations.D: Not quite. I think you have tried to add rather than multiply.

explanations.A: Make sure you are looking at all of the possible ways this could happen, I think you've only found one way.
explanations.B: If at least one ball is red that is every option except both being yellow. We can take the probability that both are yellow away from 1, so 1 – 3/7 × 2/6 = 1 – 6/42 = 36/42. You could also find the probability of picking RY, RR, YR and add them all together.
explanations.C: I think you've just found the probability of picking one red ball whilst picking only one ball out. Here, we want two balls to be picked out.
explanations.D: I think you've confused how to find the probability of picking two yellow balls

explanations.A: I think you've confused how to find the probability of picking two yellow balls
explanations.B: Make sure you are looking at all of the possible ways this could happen, I think you've only found one way.
explanations.C: If at least one ball is red that is every option except both being yellow. We can take the probability that both are yellow away from 1, so 1 − 4/9 × 3/8 = 1 − 12/72 = 60/72. You could also find the probability of picking RY, RR, YR and add them all together.
explanations.D: I think you've just found the probability of picking one red ball whilst picking only one ball out. Here, we want two balls to be picked out.

explanations.A: On the first pick there are 4 reds, on the second there would be 3 reds left, and on the third there would be 2 reds left, and so we have 4 × 3 × 2 = 24 on the numerator of the fraction.
explanations.B: Almost! I think you've found the correct values but forgotten how to find the probability of all three happening at the same time.
explanations.C: Nearly, I think you've found the numerator if there were two being picked out at once, rather than 3.
explanations.D: I think you've worked out 3 balls being replaced. If all the balls are picked out at once, then they are not being replaced.

explanations.A: Nearly, I think you've found the numerator if there were two being picked out at once, rather than 3.
explanations.B: I think you've worked out 3 balls being replaced. If all the balls are picked out at once, then they are not being replaced.
explanations.C: On the first pick there are 5 reds, on the second there would be 4 reds left, and on the third there would be 3 reds left, and so we have 5 × 4 × 3 = 60 on the numerator of the fraction.
explanations.D: Almost! I think you've found the correct values but forgotten how to find the probability of all three happening at the same time.

explanations.A: I think you've found the denominator of the probability for the first ball to be selected. How many balls can we choose from for the second ball?
explanations.B: On the first pick there are 7 balls, on the second there would be 6 balls left, and on the third there would be 5 balls left, and so we have 7 × 6 × 5 = 210 on the denominator of the fraction.
explanations.C: I think you've worked out 3 balls being replaced. If all the balls are picked out at once, then they are not being replaced.
explanations.D: Almost! I think you've found the correct values but forgotten how to find the probability of all three happening at the same time.

explanations.A: Almost! I think you've found the correct values but forgotten how to find the probability of all three happening at the same time.
explanations.B: I think you've found the denominator of the probability for the first ball to be selected. How many balls can we choose from for the second ball?
explanations.C: On the first pick there are 9 balls, on the second there would be 8 balls left, and on the third there would be 7 balls left, and so we have 9 × 8 × 7 = 504 on the denominator of the fraction.
explanations.D: I think you've worked out 3 balls being replaced. If all the balls are picked out at once, then they are not being replaced.
